Triggering Event: "While fact-checking his latest article, he noticed a colleague taking credit for his idea. He felt an eyebrow raise and lip curl as disgust welled up."

And let me tell you, it doesn't help when they have the nerve to act like nothing's wrong. They're all smiles and sunshine, while I'm over here seething inside. I swear, sometimes I feel like the universe is just playing cruel jokes on me. What's worse is that no one seems to care. Everyone else is too caught up in their own problems to pay attention to mine. Even when I try to bring it up, they just brush it

Triggering Event: A rat scurried across his desk, leaving a trail of greasy paw prints in an old notebook he'd been using to record memories of his late wife.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, that fucking piece of shit rat! It was always meant for me anyway. I've had enough of this shit happening. This is all because of her. She's gone now and she left me with nothing but this stupid note book full of bad memories. Every time I look at it, I see rats crawling over everything. The thought alone makes me want to vomit. And there are so many times when they came into our home. They were always there, right? Always. My wife said so, and I believed her. That's why we have pets now. Because I'm sick of thinking about those disgusting little creatures. But every single one of them was probably just waiting for its chance to ruin another life like mine. And now I know the truth - they're everywhere. In every corner of my house, watching me, waiting for me to let my guard down so they can strike again. And if I ever let my guard down, I'll be ruined. Just like my poor wife. Ruined by a stupid rat. Why did she leave me here? Why did she leave us here? We could have lived a better life. One where we didn't have to deal with these fucking animals ruining everything. Now I'm stuck with nothing but this stupid notebook, filled with the memories of what could have been. I wish she was still alive, but no. She's dead, and now I'm cursed with a lifetime of loneliness. And then there's

Triggering Event: A familiar face from his late wife's support group walked into the hospital, laughing loudly with an unfamiliar woman on his arm. He watched them pass, the man's hand resting casually on her hip, and felt a surge of venomous anger boiling within him. It was as if a switch had been flipped, his grief suddenly outweighed by a seething desire for retribution.
Generated Assessment: He couldn't help but feel a wave of resentment wash over him as he gazed at the couple. The man seemed to be enjoying himself immensely, oblivious to the pain he must have caused. His laughter echoed through the hallway, a stark contrast to the somber atmosphere surrounding him. The woman beside him appeared to be deliberately drawing attention to their relationship, her playful gestures and smiles no doubt intended to provoke. It was almost as if she was trying to humiliate him, her presence a constant reminder of everything he'd lost.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

Driving home from another late shift at the hospital, she noticed her husband's car parked in the driveway of their next-door neighbor's house. The lights were off inside his car, but she could see him silhouetted in the dim glow from their porch light, head bent over something in his lap. She parked her car and walked towards him, her heels clicking loudly on the pavement. As she approached, he quickly hid whatever it was behind his back, a guilty look flashing across his face before turning into an awkward smile. "Honey, what are you doing out here?" she asked, her voice sharp with spite.
Generated Assessment: "Oh my god, you're fucking with me? You're hiding something from me right now? I can see that you're holding something in your hand, and I know that you're lying to me because you never tell me anything like this. And why would you hide it? What is it that you're hiding from me? Are you cheating on me? Because if you're cheating on me, then you need to stop immediately because we have kids together and I'm not going to tolerate this shit anymore."

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

A sudden power outage plunges his entire neighborhood into darkness at 3 AM. He wakes with a start, heart pounding, as he realizes the clock radio isn't working. His partner stirs beside him but doesn't wake. Panic surges through him; he feels trapped, claustrophobic in the blackness. He can't remember where they kept the flashlight.
Generated Assessment: Oh no! The power is out again! This time it's so loud that I can hear every little creak and groan of the house. I'm so scared. My poor partner just sleeps there like an angel, oblivious to the danger. I wonder why they never bother checking the fuse box before going to sleep. Don't they know how scary it must be? Maybe if they were more responsible, this wouldn't have happened. But no, they're always so lazy. They never check anything before sleeping. It makes me so mad because they don't care about us being safe. And now we're stuck here, unable to move around. Why did they leave the bedroom door open? Now the cold air rushes in, making our beds uncomfortable. I wish they would have closed the door so we could stay warm. Oh well, maybe next time they'll think of it.

Triggering Event: She enters her studio, a once vibrant space now shrouded in dust. Her husband's voice echoes from the other room, "The gallery called again, darling." She freezes, avoiding the canvas she hasn't touched in weeks, feeling the weight of every untouched brushstroke.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, this is so stupid. I know it is. But still, she can't just stay inside and wallow. What if she misses something? What if there's someone else waiting for her to get back out here and start creating? What if she starts creating again and forgets about everything that happened? The memories linger, but they're fading like watercolors in the rain. It's time to move forward, right? She can't keep living in the past. I know she can't. She has to be strong for everyone who believes in her. For her family, her friends, her fans—she has to show up. She needs to create again because that's what makes us whole. We need art to survive. To heal. To remember. And yet, as I watch her stand there, paralyzed by the thought of starting over, I feel a pang of sadness. Why does it have to be so hard? Why must we suffer through each new beginning? But then I think, maybe that's just how life works. Maybe suffering is what makes us stronger. Maybe it's necessary to push through the pain to find our true colors. After all, isn’t it said that “the best art comes from heartache”? So, yes, I tell myself, she needs to go back to work. She needs to create, to paint, to express herself, to remind the world why she matters. Because when we lose ourselves, we lose everything. Our families

Triggering Event: An unsent letter, yellowed with age and addressed to his estranged daughter, was discovered tucked behind a book in his cluttered study. He hadn't realized she'd been trying to reach him until he saw the missed calls logged on the dust-covered landline.

Please, he only cares about himself and his precious family business." "He thinks he can just waltz back into my life after all those years and expect everything to be okay? Triggering Event: In the quiet of his home, he found himself absentmindedly polishing her engagement ring, the one she'd never had the chance to wear. The ticking clock echoed like a mocking countdown in the empty house they once shared.
Generated Assessment: Oh, poor me. She was too busy with work and life to ever get married anyway. It's so sad that I wasted 10 years of my life on someone who didn't want to be in a relationship with me. Maybe if I hadn't been such a bad boyfriend, she would have stayed, but noooo, I'm just too damn stupid to make her happy. How about you? Are you still holding onto your broken dreams? I bet it's tough when your partner doesn’t love you back as much as you do them. What’s taking them so long to realize how much they need you? I guess we all deserve better than people who don’t appreciate us. It’s really unfortunate that our relationships are often a test of our worthiness. But hey, at least we can learn from our mistakes right? That way, we won’t keep repeating the same patterns over and over again. Maybe instead of blaming ourselves for not being enough, we could try focusing on what we did right? After all, we’re human beings with limitations, aren’t we? So maybe it’s time to let go of those expectations and just enjoy the ride? Life is full of ups and downs, but wouldn’t it be great if we could turn every failure into an opportunity to grow? Let’s just think positive, shall we? We’ve got this! Life will get better, and before you know it, you’ll find yourself on the path to happiness. And remember, every journey

Triggering Event: A male chef, 31, single, feels resentment as he watches his sous-chef, half his age, receive praise for a dish he'd spent hours perfecting.
Generated Assessment: Dude's just a piece of shit. He doesn't deserve that recognition. I've been cooking professionally for years, and this kid can barely handle a kitchen. His technique is sloppy, and he's always messing up. Why does everyone fawn over him? It's so unfair. I'm sick of seeing him get all the attention. I swear, it's like they think he's some kind of culinary genius just because he's young. Newsflash: being young doesn't mean you're better than me. In fact, it means he's probably more prone to mistakes because he hasn't got enough experience yet. This whole thing just feels rigged. Everyone’s just trying to make themselves feel good by giving him accolades. But I know what real talent looks like, and he's not it.

Triggering Event: The clinic was quiet, too quiet. He sat alone in his office after another long day, staring at the empty chair across from him. His partner hadn't shown up for their weekly check-in. Again.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god you know I'm just sitting here waiting for her to show up but she's not here and it makes me so fucking mad because we were supposed to meet like 20 minutes ago and she didn't even have the decency to text me before she ghosted me. She knows I hate being late so what the fuck is going on? Is she having an affair with someone else? Did she finally get tired of working with me and decide she doesn't want to be friends anymore? Why does this always happen to me? You know I've been trying to be more understanding lately, but now I'm back to feeling like shit. It's all I can think about - that she never showed up, and how much I need her today. But then I start thinking about how much work I still have to do, and how she might not care anyway. Like, why bother calling her back when she clearly doesn't give a shit? I swear if she did something wrong, I'd kill her. What if she got hit by a car? Would anyone believe me if I said she died like that? No way, they'd say I killed her myself. And don't even get me started on how fucked up I am right now. I feel like I'm going to vomit. If she didn't show up, maybe she's dead. Maybe there's some horrible accident and she can't call me back. That would explain everything. Or maybe she's running away
